qas.question: What was Southern Italy refered to as?
Southern Italy and south-eastern Sicily were colonized by the Greeks in what century?
Who was the leading figure in Sicily during the Hellenistic period?
In 310 Agathocles invaded Tunisia and defeated what army?
In defense of Tarentum, when did Agathocles attack Italy?

context: Southern Italy (<a0_0>Magna Graecia<a0_0/>) and south-eastern Sicily had been colonized by the Greeks during the <a1_0>8th<a1_0/> century. In 4th century Sicily the leading Greek city and hegemon was Syracuse. During the Hellenistic period the leading figure in Sicily was <a2_0>Agathocles of Syracuse<a2_0/> (361 – 289 BCE) who seized the city with an army of mercenaries in 317 BCE. Agathocles extended his power throughout most of the Greek cities in Sicily, fought a long war with the Carthaginians, at one point invading Tunisia in 310 and defeating a <a3_0>Carthaginian<a3_0/> army there. This was the first time a European force had invaded the region. After this war he controlled most of south-east Sicily and had himself proclaimed king, in imitation of the Hellenistic monarchs of the east. Agathocles then invaded Italy (c. <a4_0>300 BCE<a4_0/>) in defense of Tarentum against the Bruttians and Romans, but was unsuccessful.
